questions.explanation: Saturated alkanes have formula CnH2n+2. Cycloalkanes: CnH2n. Alkenes: CnH2n. Alkynes: CnH2n-2.

questions.question_text: The most stable conformation of ethane is:
questions.explanation: Staggered conformation minimizes torsional strain by maximizing distance between C-H bonds. Eclipsed has highest strain.

options: B. Repulsion of electrons in adjacent bonds
questions.explanation: Torsional strain arises from repulsion between electron pairs in bonds on adjacent atoms when eclipsed.

questions.question_text: In butane, the anti conformation has the methyl groups:
questions.explanation: Anti conformation has bulky groups 180° apart (opposite sides). Gauche has them 60° apart.

questions.question_text: Chair cyclohexane is more stable than boat because:
options: A. Chair has more eclipsing interactions
B. Boat has flagpole interactions and eclipsing
questions.explanation: Boat has torsional strain from eclipsing and steric strain from flagpole H-H interactions. Chair avoids both.

options: B. Point up or down parallel to ring axis
questions.explanation: Axial bonds point up or down parallel to the vertical axis. Equatorial bonds point outward. Large groups prefer equatorial.
Axial substituents experience steric repulsion with axial H atoms on carbons two positions away (1,3-relationship).

options: A. Has a plane of symmetry
B. Is superimposable on its mirror image
C. Is not superimposable on its mirror image
questions.explanation: Chiral molecules are non-superimposable on their mirror images, like left and right hands. Usually requires a stereocenter.
Enantiomers are mirror images with identical physical properties except for rotation of plane-polarized light (equal and opposite).
A racemic mixture contains equal amounts of both enantiomers, so their optical rotations cancel out (optically inactive).

options: B. Priority of substituents using Cahn-Ingold-Prelog rules
questions.explanation: R/S uses CIP rules: assign priorities by atomic number, orient lowest priority away, then trace 1→2→3 (clockwise = R, counterclockwise = S).

options: D. Must have opposite optical rotation
questions.explanation: Diastereomers are stereoisomers that are NOT mirror images. They have different physical properties (mp, bp, solubility).

options: B. Is chiral despite having stereocenters
C. Is achiral despite having stereocenters due to internal symmetry
questions.explanation: Meso compounds have stereocenters but are achiral due to an internal plane of symmetry. The stereocenters 'cancel out.'
SN2 is a backside attack, causing complete inversion of configuration (Walden inversion)—the stereocenter flips like an umbrella.
SN1 goes through a planar carbocation intermediate, which can be attacked from either face, leading to racemization.

questions.question_text: Alkyl halide reactivity in SN2 follows the order:
questions.explanation: SN2 requires backside attack, which is hindered by substituents. Methyl and primary are fastest; tertiary is too hindered.
Strong nucleophiles (I⁻, CN⁻, RS⁻) favor SN2 because they actively attack the substrate. SN1 doesn't require a strong nucleophile.

options: A. Tertiary substrates and polar protic solvents
B. Primary substrates and polar aprotic solvents
questions.explanation: SN1 needs stable carbocations (tertiary best) and polar protic solvents that stabilize the carbocation and leaving group.

options: B. Weak bases (conjugate bases of strong acids)
questions.explanation: Good leaving groups are stable after leaving (weak bases). Examples: I⁻, Br⁻, OTs⁻, H₂O. Poor: OH⁻, NH₂⁻ (strong bases).

questions.question_text: The rate of an SN2 reaction depends on:
options: C. Both substrate and nucleophile concentration
questions.explanation: SN2 is bimolecular: rate = k[substrate][nucleophile]. Both concentrations appear in the rate law.

questions.question_text: In a Newman projection, the front carbon is represented by:
options: B. The point where three bonds meet
questions.explanation: In Newman projections, the front carbon is the vertex (point) where three bonds meet. The back carbon is the large circle.

questions.question_text: Ring strain in cyclopropane is due to:
options: C. Both angle strain and torsional strain
questions.explanation: Cyclopropane has angle strain (60° vs ideal 109.5°) and torsional strain (eclipsing). Both contribute to high instability.
Cyclopentane puckers to relieve torsional strain from eclipsing interactions, even though this slightly increases angle strain.

options: B. At least one double bond
questions.explanation: A stereocenter (usually sp³ carbon) has four different groups attached, making it chiral. Swapping any two groups creates the enantiomer.

questions.question_text: Optical activity is the ability to:
questions.explanation: Optically active compounds rotate plane-polarized light. (+) rotates clockwise (dextrorotatory); (-) rotates counterclockwise (levorotatory).

options: B. Concentration, path length, and wavelength
questions.explanation: [α] = α/(c × l) where α is observed rotation, c is concentration, l is path length. Temperature and wavelength also affect it.
E2 requires H and leaving group anti-periplanar (180° dihedral). This geometry allows proper orbital overlap for simultaneous elimination.
Zaitsev's rule: the more substituted (more stable) alkene is the major product in elimination reactions (thermodynamic control).
Bulky bases (t-BuO⁻) have difficulty reaching hindered protons, favoring removal of less hindered (terminal) H to give less substituted alkene.

questions.question_text: E1 reactions form carbocation intermediates like:
questions.explanation: E1 and SN1 both proceed through carbocation intermediates. They share similar conditions and often compete.

questions.question_text: Trans alkenes are generally more stable than cis because:
options: A. They have more double bond character
B. Less steric strain between substituents
questions.explanation: Trans alkenes have groups on opposite sides of the double bond, reducing steric strain compared to cis (groups on same side).

options: A. One of two equivalent groups is replaced differently
questions.explanation: Prochiral centers have two enantiotopic groups. If one is replaced (differently than the other would be), a stereocenter is created.
Complete combustion: alkane + O2 → CO2 + H2O. This is highly exothermic. Incomplete combustion can produce CO.

questions.question_text: Free radical halogenation occurs in these steps:
questions.explanation: Radical reactions: initiation (radical formation), propagation (chain reaction), termination (radicals combine). It's a chain mechanism.
Radical stability: tertiary > secondary > primary > methyl. Hyperconjugation and inductive effects stabilize radicals.

questions.question_text: Chlorination is less selective than bromination because:
options: A. Chlorine radicals are more stable
B. Chlorination is more exothermic (earlier transition state)
questions.explanation: Hammond postulate: more exothermic reactions have earlier, less selective transition states. Chlorination is more exothermic than bromination.

questions.question_text: In Fischer projections, horizontal bonds point:
options: B. Out of the page (toward viewer)
questions.explanation: Fischer convention: horizontal bonds come toward viewer (out of page), vertical bonds go away (into page). The molecule is 'flattened.'

options: C. Only allowed for meso compounds
questions.explanation: 90° rotation of Fischer projection inverts the configuration (changes R to S). 180° rotation is allowed. Swapping pairs is allowed.
Polar aprotic solvents (DMSO, DMF, acetone) don't hydrogen bond to nucleophiles, leaving them 'naked' and more reactive for SN2.
Polar protic solvents (H₂O, ROH) hydrogen bond to nucleophiles, stabilizing them and reducing their reactivity. This slows SN2.

questions.question_text: Iodide is a better nucleophile than fluoride because:
options: C. Iodide is larger and more polarizable
questions.explanation: In protic solvents, larger anions are less solvated and more nucleophilic. Iodide is also more polarizable. Nucleophilicity: I⁻ > Br⁻ > Cl⁻ > F⁻.
Epimers are diastereomers that differ in configuration at only one stereocenter. Common in carbohydrate chemistry.

options: B. Epimers at the anomeric carbon (hemiacetal carbon)
questions.explanation: Anomers are epimers specifically at the anomeric carbon (C1 in aldoses). α and β anomers differ in configuration at this hemiacetal carbon.
Chair-chair interconversion (ring flip) converts all axial positions to equatorial and vice versa. The molecule remains the same compound.

options: B. Energy difference between axial and equatorial conformers
questions.explanation: A-value is the energy difference favoring equatorial over axial position for a substituent. Larger groups have larger A-values.

options: A. Has both substituents axial or both equatorial
B. Has one axial and one equatorial
D. Is always less stable than cis
questions.explanation: In trans-1,4, substituents are on opposite faces. In one chair, both are equatorial; after ring flip, both are axial.

options: B. Steric interactions between groups 60° apart
C. Found only in eclipsed conformations
D. Always more stable than anti
questions.explanation: Gauche interactions occur between groups 60° apart (in staggered conformations). They're higher energy than anti but lower than eclipsed.
Decalin has cis and trans isomers based on how the two rings are fused. Trans-decalin is more stable but cannot ring-flip.

questions.question_text: Resolution of racemic mixtures can be achieved by:
options: B. Reaction with chiral reagent to form diastereomers
questions.explanation: Enantiomers have identical physical properties. Converting them to diastereomers (using chiral reagent) creates different properties for separation.

options: A. Converting one enantiomer to another
B. Producing a 50:50 mixture of enantiomers from one pure enantiomer
questions.explanation: Racemization is the process of converting a pure enantiomer into a racemic mixture (50:50 of both enantiomers), resulting in loss of optical activity.
